Patch Set 38:

(9 comments)

Please try to make the commit subject a little more succinct. Currently it exceeds the recommended column count by a fair margin.

Also, you should follow convention and prefix the subject with the subsystem touched by the patch. In this case you're changing some code specific to Meta, so this should be:

```
oem: meta: <description>
```
Done. Please check.
Done
If you have a numbered/bulleted list of things your patch is doing, it's _very_ they should be implemented as separate patches.
"_very_ likely", that is
Done. Please check.
Removing the content of the commit message was not what I was after. I've split the changes.

The `Signed-off-by` email address _must_ match the author. As an author you are not listed on Wywinn's CLA.

By project policy I can't accept this contribution until you are party to the CLA.
Done. Please check.
Done
Hi Jeff. I have a number of comments inline, but also you must update the changelog with any details affecting the public API of the project.

See my comment in the implementation.

At the very least this change needs to be in a separate patch.
Done. Please check.
You need to keep the declaration of the old function name as well, for backwards compatibility. But also, can you please split this into a separate patch?
Done
This needs doxygen documentation covering the parameters and enumerating the possible return values.
Done. Please check.
Done
Can we define these in a struct instead and pass a pointer in?
Done. Please check.
Done
This seems unrelated to file IO. Why is it in this header? Also, it should be a separate patch and it needs doxygen comments covering the parameters and enumerating the possible return values.

Add doxygen comments done.
The reason related to file IO is to read the data of the file.
This needs at least be called `encode_oem_meta_http_boot_header_resp()`
Done

As this is an API marked `LIBPLDM_ABI_STABLE` we mustn't just rename it, as it's an API/ABI break. Through the documented processes I'm trying to encourage good discipline here, to keep the library easy to use and upgrade.

I started collecting a checklist of things to work through before submitting patches. It should help address some of the issues with this patch:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md

Specifically, see:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md#removing-an-api

and

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/README.md#the-abi-lifecycle

Renaming a function requires introducing a new function with the new name without yet deleting the old one.

I have some work in this area as I also want to rename a bunch of functions. I'll push that and you can base this change on it.

Finally, renaming this function should happen in its own patch, not mixed with other changes, and needs an entry in the changelog.
See https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/71967 for some guidance on renaming a stable function.
Done. Please check.
Done

If we're "renaming" the function then can you please take the opportunity to make the new function return a negative errno?

See https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L108-L112

There's an internal-only API for doing error code translation that will be useful here:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/src/api.h#L10-L43

If modified to return a negative value, errors will occur when using the check items of the decode_oem_meta_write_file_io_req function.

reference
https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/tests/oem/meta/fileio.cpp#L44
https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/tests/oem/meta/fileio.cpp#L61
https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/tests/oem/meta/fileio.cpp#L76
Please also fix the tests.
Done

The double-underscore was meant to be a suggestion that you shouldn't call this function directly, and the direct invocation is the cause of your CI failure.

You must instead choose from `pldm_msgbuf_init_cc()` or `pldm_msgbuf_init_errno()`. As this the implementation of a function marked `LIBPLDM_ABI_STABLE`, you mustn't change the behaviour of the returned error codes. As such you should use `pldm_msgbuf_init_cc()`.

However, for future reference, it's strongly preferred that newly added functions return negative errnos and _not_ PLDM completion codes. This is because the _implementation_ can have error states that can't be described in terms of protocol-level completion codes.
Done. Please check.
Done

New functions must be marked `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`, with a subsequent stabilisation patch linking to a demonstration of their use in another open source project. See:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/README.md#requirements-for-stabilising-a-function
Done. Please check.
See query on the header about whether this should be a struct. Passing so many uint8_t pointers is going to make the call-site easy to get wrong.
Modified to pass structure pointer.
Done
This would need to test the rest of the pointers as well. If you pass a struct pointer there are many fewer concerns.
Modified to pass structure pointer.
Done
New functions are _strongly_ preferred to return negative errno values. Also with the renaming of the write function we have an opportunity to keep that consistent.
Done. Please check.
Done
Accounting for the error-handling comment on line 49 above, this should be `plmd_msgbuf_init_errno()`.
Done. Please check.
Done
This must be `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING` for now.
Done. Please check.
Negative errno for errors. `-EINVAL` in this case.
Done, Please check.
Done

Please

```
#include "dsp/base.h"
```

and switch to `pack_pldm_header_errno()`, fixing the test on line 82 as well.
Done. Please check.
Done
`return 0;`
Done. Please check.

How is HTTP boot messaging related to file IO? Why is there no discussion of the API break? What about the other new API?

Ultimately this patch needs to be split into 3 separate patches.

Hi Andrew, 
I have modified the content according to the suggestions.

Here are some replies to some parts.
1. There is no modification to the "decode_oem_meta_write_file_io_req" function, because all functions that use this function use PLDM completion code to determine the result.

2. How is HTTP boot messaging related to file IO ? Why is there no discussion of the API break?
- To use http boot, you need to enable http boot by confirming whether the certification is correct. Therefore, we need to use the read file IO command to read whether the certification of http boot is correct. When an exception occurs during encode/decode, the function will be break.
Done. Please check.

Hi,

There are still many unresolved comments fromn PS2, and chopping content out of the commit message was not what I was ultimately asking for on PS2. Please work to address all the unresolved comments.

Also, I won't be merging a patch that doesn't pass CI. Please iterate on it to make it pass. Addressing the unresolved comments should go a long way towards fixing that.

Hi Andrew,
I have modified the content according to the suggestions.
If you have any questions, please let me know, thank you.
Hi; I'm going to pull this down and make some fixes myself, then push it back. I'd appreciate it if you test it and adjust change as necessary once I've done so.

Okay, I've split this up. Please see the subsequent few commits. They have `wip:` in their subject; please work to tidy them up as required. Working through the checklist will help:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md

Hi Andrew,
I will include subsequent commits to retest whether the features we want to support work properly.
When the test passes, I will report the test results in subsequent commits.
Thank you.

Super, thanks.

I'll re-review this and the following patches once you have done your tests.

Please no more structs marked `__attribute__((packed))` in the public API. I put together a checklist that's helpful for adding new APIs, and avoiding this is one of the items in the list:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L82-L83
Done

New functions should return negative errno values, not PLDM completion codes. Please see:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L119-L123
Done

Negative errno values please, not PLDM completion codes:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L119-L123
Done

I've split the commit up, so this will need to be rewritten to reflect what's actually going on in the patch. Can you please do so? Perhaps:

```
oem: meta: Add decode_oem_meta_write_file_io_req()
```

Hi Andrew,
Done. The commit content has been modified according to the suggestions.
Rebase main and force update this branch to resolve conflicts.
I prefer we re-order `write` in the name, so `decode_oem_meta_file_io_write_req(...)`.
Done
Can you please mention how the behaviour of `decode_oem_meta_file_io_write_req()` is different to `decode_oem_meta_file_io_req()`?
Done. Please check, thank you.
This is an unrelated change? Please move it to the appropriate commit.

Done. (Remove the unrelated change)
Please check, thank you.

This is not true. `decode_oem_meta_file_io_write_req()` now returns 0 on success or a negative errno value on failure. That is _unlike_ `decode_oem_meta_file_io_req()`, which returns PLDM_SUCCESS on success, or another PLDM completion code on failure.
Sorry for not explaining this part of the change. Modifications have been made according to suggestions, please check thank you.

Hi Lora, I just realised that this API is quite broken in terms of memory safety. In light of that, I can't accept the rework being marked as `LIBPLDM_ABI_STABLE` as it is, it must become `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING` and the interface fixed.

Please also expand the test case to demonstrate that the implementation returns an error if memory safety would be violated.
Please describe a struct to contain these values rather than passing individual pointers.

Has been changed to input struct rather than passing individual pointers.
Please check, thank you.

The doxygen says this is an out-parameter, which can only mean that the decoding writes data into it. `length` is not documented as an `in` parameter, so the upshot is that we're never specifying the length of the array pointed to by `data` to the function, which means it cannot be safe. This API must be fixed so it's possible to implement well-defined behaviour.

The input parameters have been modified according to the suggestions.
Please check, thank you.
Done
Please change this to `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`, based on the memory safety issue discussed below.
Done. Please check, thank you.

Sorry, I only just looked more closely at this, and this is not at all safe. At no point is the length of the region pointed to by `data` provided, and we're just assuming the length provided in the message won't exceed the buffer. This is CVE-worthy stuff, and I'm bothered that it's made its way into the codebase as it is.

The extraction results will be checked to see if any errors occurred.
Please check, thank you.
Hi, I have several concerns still with this.
Please don't update the ABI dumps for patches that aren't stabilisation patches.
I have revised it back. Thank you.
Why `uint32_t` and not `size_t`?
Done. Please check, thank you.

You can't change this API as its definition is not marked `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`. This change breaks the stable ABI contract and any software that depends on it. The only thing you can do for safety is to stop using it and switch to a better API like we're trying to design above.
I have revised it back. Thank you.
Done. Please check, thank you.

You might as well pass `UINT32_MAX` for compatibility here, as that's what the code was effectively already assuming. You can't fix this API by adding the `data_length` parameter because it's not marked `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`, it's is just broken and we have to live with it, as discussed on the header.
